chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil.And I'm Beth.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: And since my dreams are now shattered, why don't we spend the rest of this programme finding out exactly what is going on inside our bodies and brains

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: when we fall in love. And of course, learn some useful new vocabulary too.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: According to Helen E Fisher, self-help author and anthropologist at Rutgers University, there are three aspects of romantic love.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: Helen Fisher thinks the first aspect of

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: love is purely physical, lust, the strong feeling of sexual desire for someone. Lust is driven by the hormones estrogen in women and testosterone in men. A few people are asexual, meaning they don't feel sexual attraction for anyone of any gender.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: Of course, love is not just physical. Here's BBC Ideas again to introduce Helen Fisher's second aspect of love, attraction.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: Here, though, there's a downside. The dopamine hit of sexual attraction feels so good, we crave it more and more. Some people are always chasing the next relationship to get a new hit.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: It's fascinating to see the power which hormones have over us. But if you're an old-fashioned romantic like Neil, don't despair. And speaking as a romantic, how about the answer to my question?

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: I guessed it was that their heartbeats harmonise. Which was the correct answer. In experiments, looking into the eyes produced hormones causing couples' hearts to beat in time. OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt in this programme, starting with the idiom head over heels, to be completely in love with someone.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: The phrase it's fair to say is used to introduce a statement you believe to be true and reasonable. The adjective feel good describes something which makes people feel happy and optimistic. And finally the idiom stuck in a loop describes someone unable to break the habit of repeating the same negative patterns of behaviour over and over again.

chunks.episode_title: The science of falling in love
chunks.chunk_text: For more topical discussion and useful vocabulary here at 6 Minute English, goodbye for now. Bye.
